Title: The Politics and Practice of Social Media in Conflict

This five-year project aims to investigate the complex relationship between social media and conflict, with a specific focus on Africa, particularly Eastern Africa. The initiative seeks to extend internet reach to remote regions and improve affordable access to the world's poorest populations in non-urban areas with weak state presence, where protracted violent conflict is prevalent. Our research will explore the key puzzle of whether social media access promotes peace-building or perpetuates violence in conflict-affected communities.

Through a comprehensive examination of the interplay between social media and conflict, we will address three primary research questions: How does social media alter transnational dimensions of conflict and peacebuilding? How do public authorities use social media to encourage violence or promote peace? And, how is social media changing people's experiences with violent conflict? Our analysis will be situated within four contexts: dangerous speech online, exit and entry of individuals from/into conflict, actors' tactics to shape the Internet, and governance actors' use of social media.

By shedding light on the dynamics of social media in conflict settings, this project will provide critical insights for policymakers, practitioners, and scholars working to promote peace and stability in Africa. Our findings will inform strategies for harnessing social media to build peace and mitigate violence, ultimately contributing to more effective conflict resolution and peacebuilding efforts in the region.
